title: Tuesday, 8th March, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Morning

PM

And Happy International Women's Day

BE

thumbs up

11:02 am
PM

With it being International Women's Day guess we should have a female pic of the day

PM

Before I hand over to Bryce

PM

On the subject some of you will want to discuss

11:02 am
PM

Burberry

PM

Let me see

PM

Female in the news...

11:02 am
PM

hmmm

PM

Have a video

PM
11:02 am
BE

(@Mo: you're sitting this one out, okay? Bye.)

PM

Everyone's dropping Ms Sharapova like a stone

PM

Nike etc

11:03 am
PM

Personally, seems a bit hasty to me

PM

Think we might invite her to Camp AV

PM

Hear her side of the story in full

11:04 am
PM

Anyway, I have another female image to share

PM

BE

Can't say I recognise her. Who's that?

11:04 am
PM

Elinor Ostrom

PM

The only woman to win the Nobel for economics

BE

embarassed smile

11:05 am
PM

75 men, one woman

PM

Shocking eh?

PM

Actually, UBS have some history on her (Elinor died in 2012)

11:05 am
PM

https://www.ubs.co...elinor-ostrom.html

PM

Elinor C. Ostrom, the first female Nobel Laureate in Economic Sciences, believed that people are perfectly capable of taking control of decisions that affect their lives, without external authorities imposing rules. Her extensive fieldwork focused on how people interact with ecosystems, such as forests, fisheries and irrigation systems, while maintaining the long-term sustainability of these resources.

PM

Her findings proved how societies develop diverse management systems. Rather than imposing a singular ‘panacea’ to manage these multi-faceted interactions, she identified eight ‘design principles’ for stable, common pool resource management. She outlined these principles in her 1990 book, Governing the Commons : The Evolution of Institutions for Collective Action, which showed how shared resources can be managed by local people.

11:06 am
PM

had a brief chat with UBS's Tao Wang earlier

PM

head of China economics there

PM

She was saying how Elinor was not even permitted to do her doctorate in economics, cos of some stupid rule

11:07 am
PM

Had to do it in political science instead -- and still went on to win the Nobel

PM

Actually, Tao was interesting on her own background

PM

Apparently, in China, in the wake of the cultural revolution, young people went into science and tech because it was "safe"

11:08 am
PM

Less likely to say something and end up breaking rocks in the country side

PM

PM

Anyway, will try and share more of Tao's stuff later

11:09 am
PM

Given the news flow out of China

PM

but first....

undefined
11:09 am
PM

Bryce?

PM

What have you started??

PM

http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz42J3iD2Ha

11:09 am
BE

Hm. Hang on, just heading Ostrom's wiki.

BE

She was the only child of a musician and a set designer. I guess the only way to rebel was to become an economist.

BE

Anyway, yes, I guess we need to do Burberry.

11:10 am
Burberry Group PLC (BRBY:LSE): Last: 1,454, up 83 (+6.05%), High: 1,459, Low: 1,421, Volume: 2.60m
PM

High quality global journalism requires investment. Please share this article with others using the link below, do not cut & paste the article. See our Ts&Cs and Copyright Policy for more detail. Email ftsales.support@ft.com to buy additional rights. http://www.ft.com/...html#ixzz42JChX8jb

A mystery investor has built up a stake of close to 5 per cent in Burberry, prompting Britain’s best-known luxury fashion brand to seek help from its financial advisers to defend it against any potential takeover bid.
Burberry, with a market capitalisation of £6bn, sought aid after its board could not determine the identity of the stakebuilder.

PM

rocket

11:10 am
BE

Even though I'm going to say exactly what I said to the several dozen people who phoned this morning.

BE

Everything we know is in the story.

PM

Yeah, but that doesnt stop us asking more questions

11:11 am
BE

We've no idea who's stake building, and our speculation is no more useful than anyone else's speculation.

PM

A person close to the company said that it had attempted unsuccessfully to ask HSBC, which is listed as the custodian for the position, to reveal its client.

BE

All we know is that Burberry's been spooked enough to bring in Robey Warshaw.

11:11 am
PM

This is against company law, surely?

PM

Not bringing in Simon Robey

BE

Well .............. One could make that case too.

11:11 am
PM

HSBC refusing to reveal beneficial owner

BE

But, yes, warehousing for a secret buyer isn't really considered cricket.

BE

And as we know, there are ways to shake out the name of the underlying holder.

11:13 am
BE

As in, file a 793 Notice.

PM

New name for 212 notices

PM

new ish

11:13 am
BE

Yep, there was a transparency regime rejig late last year I think.

BE

And no-one's entirely sure how to come with it.

BE

(Come = cope. Typo. Sorry.)

11:14 am
BE

So anyway .....

BE

What we can do is retrace the Burberry buyout argument.

BE

Clearly there's the luxury consolidation angle, and there are obvious candidates there.

11:15 am
BE

But there's also the LBO angle.

BE

Which is where things get a bit more complicated.

BE

So Burberry's leases, including contingent leases, are capitalised at five times the annual minimum lease charge.

11:16 am
PM

omg smile

BE

All of which adds up to nearly £2bn

BE

That means you get a lease adjusted net debt of nearly £1.4bn, which makes the LBO maths scary.

11:17 am
BE

But you also get an actual net debt of £550m if the leases are treated less conservatively.

BE

Which makes the LBO maths look pretty decent.

PM

hmm

11:17 am
PM

I will take your word for this

BE

Our friends at Aviate had a run at the theme this morning.

BE

Forever a bid target given its digestible size (£6bn) and lack of blocking (family) stake, the mystery stake-builder adds fuel to the bid-spec fire. Most M&A in the sector tends to be of much smaller size, but then luxury stocks have been in an earnings downgrade cycle, so this may be the opportunity to get Burberry. It's really a very vague story, 'someone' is building a position. Whether that is a strategic investor or not, it will get the industry players thinking more seriously about running the slide-rule over Burberry.

On our back of the envelope LBO numbers, the IRR is only 6%, but this is because we are using consensus EBITDA over the next 2y which has 0 EBITDA growth (IRR model assumes 30% premium, 60% debt funded, 6% cost of debt). An industry player (like LVMH) would take a longer term view rather than looking for a nice turn in 3y. Such an acquirer would be able to get some modest synergies out to make the LBO maths work better, as well as have a cost of debt much lower than 6%. So, for an industry player, the numbers would stack up much better.

11:18 am
BE

At the lows, BRBY traded at a PE discount to the market and the basic DCF valuation had 0% FCF growth forever assuming an 8% WACC. For a company that still generates a 15% cash ROIC (brilliant) and has grown FCF at a 14% CAGR in the last 10y, we thought the market had got far too bearish on it. After a +4% move on Tuesday, the stock is on 20x (we assume trough) F12m PE (above the 5y avg of 17.5) and a trailing FCF yield of 5% (still good).

BE

On a basic DCF, the current share price equates to 0% FCF growth for 5y then 2% into perpetuity at an 8% WACC - so for LT term luxury investors (and industry players?) there is still value - and this is what they will be looking at. At this stage, it's a vague FT report, but the story is not going to go away.

BE

I'd also like to revisit an old Macquarie note, about a month old.

11:19 am
BE

Which sets out the broader case well.

PM

Go on then

BE

(It seems, perhaps for International Women's Day, that we called the Macquarie analyst Daniele Gianera a "ms" in the paper ... he is in fact a chap.)

11:20 am
BE

(We're fixing that currently.)

PM

(oops)

BE

We believe Burberry continues to execute with success in a challenging environment for the
entire industry and remains a leader despite margin improvement continuing to be postponed. Burberry should be net cash by c£640m by March 2016, based on our modelling. We believe at current valuation there is a real acquisition target probability around Burberry, given the cash is 12% of current market cap and FCF Yield is above 5%. It could emerge as acquisition target once again as was several times the case in the past (FT and Bloomberg).

11:21 am
BE

Burberry is one of the few luxury brands without family interest and thus an easier target for
acquisition. The investments into the IT platform and the innovation in digital make Burberry
the leader in exploiting new technologies to better manage operations and capture growth.
We believe this represents attractive know-how for an eventual buyer of the business to be
replicated on other brands.

BE

BE

We analysed the past 15 years of M&A history in the luxury sector where we counted over
c300 deals across public and private companies for an estimated total transaction amount of
$45bn, over half of the size of LVMH’s market value. Thanks to the strong cash generation
and the high level of cash on balance sheets in the sector, we are not surprised to find out
that about 60% of the transactions have been paid in cash. The average EBIT and EBITDA
multiple paid over the past 15 years was 13.9x and 18.7x, respectively.

11:21 am
BE

BE

In the scenario of a bid for Burberry, we apply a 10% discount to historical multiples. On our
estimates this implies Burberry could be valued c£8bn or c1,700p p/share.

BE

11:21 am
BE

That's a really good backgrounder note, if you have time to dig it out.

BE

And that, I think, is all we have to say there. Please stop phoning.

undefined

BE

FTSE's down, incidentally.

PM

Down a good bit

BE

Off 0.8% at 6131. It was about this level yesterday before the miners rallied.

11:23 am
BE

Today, the miners are all down again.

PM

un-rallied

BE

Yep. All we can say here is that they trade like penny stocks and 10% moves are basically just daily noise.

11:23 am
Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 574.90, down 53.2 (-8.47%), High: 610.10, Low: 565.40, Volume: 6.09m
Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 158.93, down 11.82 (-6.92%), High: 165.25, Low: 156.25, Volume: 41.51m
Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 2,132, down 105.5 (-4.72%), High: 2,158, Low: 2,120, Volume: 2.78m

BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 855.40, down 42.4 (-4.72%), High: 861.80, Low: 837.70, Volume: 7.02m
PM

Just extraordinary

BE

What we do have leading us down, though, is Worldpay.

11:24 am
BE

Which isn't a miner.

Worldpay Group PLC (WPG:LSE): Last: 267.40, down 24.5 (-8.39%), High: 289.10, Low: 264.70, Volume: 3.63m
PM

But trading like one today

11:24 am
BE

Maiden results are "broadly" in line.

BE

And by "broadly" I mean not.

PM

http://www.investe...1603080700093235R/

11:25 am
BE

The US is the big problem.

BE

With costs running ahead of guidance.

BE

And EBITDA down 17% YoY

11:26 am
BE

Which isn't the kind of thing you expect of a stock priced for growth.

BE

There was a US management change at the end of 2015, with the eCom head dropped in to try and stabilise things.

BE

But it's not exactly great for confidence to have your US division hit the gravel so soon after flotation.

11:27 am
BE

Here's Barclays.

BE

Worldpay’s FY15 results are broadly in line with company consensus on headline metrics with medium-term guidance unchanged. Beneath the surface, the core UK and eCom businesses are outperforming, while the situation in the US has remained more challenging than expected. US costs were running ahead of our and management expectations, but this was compensated by solid UK performance and therefore overall numbers were inline. FY15 net revenue of £981.7m was 1.8% ahead of company consensus for 2H15, while FY underlying EBITDA of £406.1m was 0.4% shy in H2. FY adj. EPS of 6.9p was in line with 7.0p consensus. All three regions saw revenue growth ahead of our expectations with 17% growth in eCom, 11% in the UK and 15% in the US (3% organic). However, at an EBITDA level, the performance was more divergent: eCom and the UK were 1.3% and 2.3% ahead respectively of our estimates, while the US transition was more costly than expected and at £62.3m of EBTIDA missed our estimate by £9.8m, hence there was not a beat at the profit line. FCF at £32.4m was also in line with our expectation.

PM

Jeepers, ive just got to the bottom of the statement, where they've hidden the un-gilded figures

11:28 am
PM

They are as ugly as hell

PM

A selection..

PM

11:01 am
PM

Welcome to Markets Live

PM

How you magic those into the allegedly underlying picture advertised at the top of the statement, ive no idea

BE

I struggle to see why Worldpay deserves the rating it has, other than "it was sold from a distressed owner to two PE funds who did an excellent job of ramping it out the door."

11:30 am
BE

Still, I'm in the minority. Here's Morgan Stanley, also buying.

BE

Worldpay delivered slightly better than expected revenues and adj.
EBITDA in-line with MS / street. The UK did better, the US slightly worse
and we expect Worldpay to highlight the need for continued
investment in the US business. There was no specific guidance for 2016,
but we expect street revenues to move up 2/3% and street adj. EBITDA
to be unchanged. We think the buy-side consensus was for an EBITDA
beat and potentially some 2016 upgrades and so with the shares on 27x
2016e P/E, we likely see some weakness in the shares short term.
However, we believe investing for sustainable growth is the correct
strategy. We remain OW and would have strong conviction if the shares
approach 20-22x 2017e P/E (260-270p).

BE

Credit Suisse. Also buying.

11:31 am
BE

Behind the headlines: WPUK performed well during the period, with 11%
net revenue growth and robust profitability. Net revenue/ transaction ticked
up to 0.2% vs 0.19% last year and management indicates that the majority of
Interchange impacts have been re-invested into the business. Global eCom
similarly performed well (17% net revenue growth and 14% EBITDA growth),
reflecting the group's strong market position and strength of the market
opportunity. The one slight disappointment is in the US where underlying
growth was just 3% due to the lag in new partners contributing to revenue.
This division is likely to need continued investment going into FY16.
■ Outlook and forecast: The outlook points to a strong start to 2016, and
confidence in 9-11% net revenue growth. However, ongoing investment
means that margin leverage is not expected until 2H17. We leave underlying
constant currency growth at 10%, but upgrade FY16 revenues by 4% due to
FX (3%) and the higher than expected starting run rate (1%). We upgrade
FY16 EBITDA by 1% due to FX, but we were below consensus. We expect
consensus to remain broadly unchanged, with scope for a c2% underlying
EBITDA downgrade (due to lower margins), offset by a similar positive FX
impact.

BE

(@cleverhedge: yep, you seem to.)

PM

(cleverhedge - nope)

11:32 am
undefined
BE

Back to the risers?

PM

Sure

11:32 am
BE

Kantar data looks positive-ish.

BE

Though it needs that "ish", because the headline figures look pretty awful.

BE

The big four are still losing share, but none is losing share as fast as Asda

11:33 am
BE

Which has been losing share for 22 consecutive Kantars.

PM

blimey

BE

That distorts the figures.

11:34 am
BE

Whereas Tesco loses a mere 21 bips, its best since January 15, which is in spite of store closures.

BE

I'd also highlight that Morrison looks pretty poor -- down 39 bips -- ahead of its Q4 results due Thursday.

WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 203.50, down 5.9 (-2.82%), High: 207.40, Low: 202.80, Volume: 4.01m
11:34 am
Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 196.16, up 4.36 (+2.27%), High: 198.00, Low: 189.15, Volume: 11.32m
BE

Barclays provides the most readable table.

BE

11:35 am
BE

Though your mileage may vary.

BE

And here's the working.

BE

Kantar has released UK market share data for the 4 weeks to 28 February 2016. There are no dramatic new trends in evidence this month, but the data does suggest that Tesco’s improved trading over recent months is continuing – with a 21bps market share loss being its smallest such loss since January 2015 (and much less than the average loss of c50bps across the last year). By contrast, Morrison’s share loss of 39bps is its highest share loss since October 2014 – albeit the Morrison data is hard to analyse given it is not adjusted for the store closures the company has undertaken. ASDA’s share loss of 65bps is a welcome improvement from the 79bps loss seen last time, but this still represents one of the worst months on record for the company. The discounters’ growth seems to be continuing at a similar pace to last month.

11:36 am
BE

(@St Andrean: there was a large seller trying to clear at basically any price, I believe. It's not terribly liquid and, given its ownership structure and its slightly tricky record with disclosures, big sellers before results tend to be seen as a worrying sign.)

BE

And for the detail, here's Morgan Stanley.

BE

Deflation & polarization remain acute: Deflation stood at -1.6% YoY over
12wks, in line with P1 figures, suggesting price pressures are not abating. We
continue to expect a deflationary environment over the next quarters, in part
because of the Big 4's unsustainable 15%+ price gap vs. discounters.
Meanwhile, underperformance of the Big 4 continued, conceding -233bps to
the market (vs. -240 bps in P1 and -158bps in P13 last year). As we discuss
below, this was mainly driven by Asda's decline. Sales growth at discounters
Aldi/Lidl remained elevated at +16% in P2 (vs. ~+18% in P1) – with Lidl again
outgrowing Aldi. The Co-op (6.1% market share), a market share donor over
the past decade, had one of its best performances for a long time in February.

11:37 am
BE

Morrisons' good performance at Xmas not repeated... Morrisons'
underperformance vs. the rest of the market widened sequentially for the 2nd
month in a row (-489bps in P2 vs. -380 bps in P1 and -256bps in last year's
P13). While the underperformance is partially driven by store closures
(impacting sales by around -1.5% in both periods), the sequential deterioration
might be due to a lower benefit from promotions (particularly in alcohol). We
would also stress that this performance was achieved in a context where Asda
(the retailer with which Morrison has the greatest overlap) is posting its worst
monthly performance in more than 15 years.

PM

Goodness, that's pretty brutal on Asda

BE

What's Asda going to do? Really, how long does Wal-Mart persist with this?

11:38 am
BE

Argos would be the obvious solution -- certainly more obvious than for Sainsbury -- but there's been no indication whatsoever that Clarke would be allowed to pursue that.

BE

… in a context where Asda continues to face the greatest pressure in UK
grocery, with another record poor performance (-531bps vs. market, very
close from last month's absolute -539bps record). Asda remains the worst
performing Top 10 grocer, by a wide margin. Kantar data imply a negative LFL
sales contraction of ~-6% so far in 1Q, which would be Asda's worst LFL in
more than 50 years. We believe that Asda has been protecting its P&L in the past year at
the expense of its market share, coinciding with a clear deterioration of its
price position. As we detail in Asda: What's wrong? we believe Asda's parent
company Walmart (covered by Simeon Gutman) could push it to change
course this year. Asda's CEO Clarke has already announced an incremental
£500m of price cuts, an assortment rationalisation and more aggressive
marketing. But so far, our UK AlphaWise Price Tracker suggests price cuts
have remained modest compared to peers (albeit more important on the most
commonly stocked items at the Big 4).

BE

Kantar data suggest good momentum at Sainsbury, and a respectable
one at Tesco. Despite a tougher comp base, Sainsbury improved sequentially,
growing 60bps ahead of the market (vs. in line in P1). Tesco underperformed
by -130 bps, a touch better than last month's -147bps. Kantar data (adj.)
suggest little change in Tesco's LFL sales run-rate over the last 4 weeks of its
4Q, at ~+0.5% (broadly in line with consensus).

11:39 am
J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 268.80, down 1.7 (-0.63%), High: 270.80, Low: 267.30, Volume: 1.20m
BE

Meanwhile, elsewhere on the Tesco front .....

BE

Two pushes. Firstly from Bruno at Bernstein

11:40 am
BE

Who backtests his thesis that the 2.2% long term UK margin baked into the consensus "doesn't make sense."

BE

Even though it's a huge leap from the 0.8% margin Tesco reported for the first half.

BE

Bernstein's on a 3% margin for Tesco, and argues that the consensus will move that direction soon enough.

11:41 am
BE

And from that, Bernstein reverse engineers the share price.

BE

Looking at how the markets trade, Tesco gets valued on its UK margin "2 years out " (12 to 24 months out). That justifies recent share price movements around £1.70. With 2 margin updates in the next 12 months (April for H2 of 2015/16 and October for H1 of 2016/17) we see sufficient data points for consensus UK margins to be revised upwards by 80 bps to 3.0%. That combined with better sentiment around the stock and rolling forward the impact of cash generation are sufficient to get us to £2.50 in 12 months' time.

BE

Adding another year of margin development would support a recovery valuation of £3.20 two years out. We rate Tesco Outperform with a Target Price of £2.50.

11:41 am
BE

(I do like Bernstein stuff, as a rule. It's inventive.)

BE

Meanwhile, Macquarie also pushing Tesco

BE

 TSCO could beat on Retail expectations: While TSCO reiterated that they
are comfortable with overall FY16 £930mn Consensus Operating Profit we
believe they could beat that. Moreover, we believe that Consensus profits for
Bank are far too high and don’t account for Interchange fees. As a result we
expect it to deliver a better Retail Operating Profit than Consensus.
 UK profit bridge suggests TSCO could beat: We note several potential
positive moving parts in our bridge for 2H 15/16 Operating Profit: higher cost
savings run rate vs. 1H, recovering part of the better trading terms, unwind of
Fuelsave, loss making stores, online initiatives and Blinkbox losses and of
course far better sales and operating leverage. More art than science but our
profit bridge implies £360mn 2H profit vs. Cons of £325mn. We remain 11%
and 7% ahead for the next two years at the Group trading profit as well.
 International should be stronger too: Sales recovery in International has
been even better than in the UK with a very healthy LFL growth. The return of
operating leverage, cost savings and a reversal of Hungarian tax provision
should all mean International should at least meet expectations.
 Equity story coming together – all about FCF: Confidence in the margin
recovery should start to increase with FY16 results, which should provide a
cleaner profit base from which we should find it is easier to rebuild. The key
attraction for us is the 8-10% FCF yield thanks to which it should reach
investment grade threshold of c3.6x adjusted gearing by FY18.

11:42 am
BE

And that's enough grocers.

PM

Phew. Thanks for all that.

undefined
11:43 am
PM

We ignoring Pearson?

Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 874.00, up 7 (+0.81%), High: 876.50, Low: 856.00, Volume: 772.47k
BE

I was planning to.

11:44 am
PM

Glad I unilaterally closed our short

PM

Can see any fresh sell side

BE

...... Ditto. Think it's just a deadcat

11:45 am
PM

Well it's certainly a bouncy cat

PM

This is up from circa 650p...

undefined
11:46 am
BE

If we want to stick among the risers, though, I was meaning to note Admiral.

BE

Which I think is a record high today.

Admiral Group PLC (ADM:LSE): Last: 1,975, up 11 (+0.56%), High: 1,993, Low: 1,967, Volume: 508.49k
11:46 am
BE

Think we flagged Admiral a month or so ago, based solely on one of those nebulous "mind yer eye" type rumours.

BE

It's had very good results post that.

BE

And of course, Henry Engelhardt retires in May

11:47 am
BE

He's still holding an 11.6% stake.

BE

Biggest holder ahead of Munich Re, with 10.1%.

BE

Anyway, I note it only because Nomura's pushing this morning.

11:48 am
BE

Favour car insurers, rates recovering, etc.

BE

• The sector presents attractive total returns; special dividends have been a feature for both DLG and Admiral, leading to strong yields. We highlight Solvency II is leading to excess capital returns as Admiral and DLG release prior capital conservatism.
• The sector is defensive; it has lower balance sheet risk than life peers and limited exposure to the business cycle compared with other sectors.
• There are bottom-up fundamentals driving performance; Restructuring in the case of RSA; UK motor rates and special dividends in the case of Admiral and DLG.

BE

And in terms of Admiral specifically .....

11:48 am
BE

Admiral has reported PBT 8% ahead of consensus and DPS 3% ahead. The total dividend for the year is 100.0p (93% payout ratio), and the group comments that the final is made up of ordinary and special, with the special including 11.9p reflecting the first element of a phased return of surplus capital given the Group’s Solvency II capital position. The Solvency II ratio (Standard Model) is a strong 206%, vs DLG 147% (Standard Model) and RSA 155% (Internal Model). Admiral is targeting a ratio of 125-150%.

BE

Some changes in the composition of the dividend …
Although Admiral officially has paid an ordinary and a special, the market has traditionally assumed a c95% payout ratio (cons 2016/2017 payout ratio is 95%), and we note that the divi ex the phased capital return equates to a payout ratio of 82%.

BE

… but medium-term dividend should be fine
However, the group comments that it will apply for the Partial Internal model during 2017, and capital return will be phased (£150-200m, or around 53-71p, over two to three years), and the group expects “for the foreseeable future at least, to continue to distribute, in total, the same proportion of our earnings as in the past.” “To be in [the] order of 90-95%”. So there is some rearranging of the normal/specials, but the dividend medium term should be fine, if slightly more complicated.

11:49 am
BE

Return to earnings growth
Admiral grew the UK motor business in 2015, with vehicles up 5%, as the group increased rates somewhat less than the market. Admiral expects continued premium increases likely in 2016, though believes prospects for small bodily injury reform creates uncertainty. We can continue to expect “sustained, material” reserve releases in 2016 as well to help earnings.

BE

Pure play on UK motor
Admiral performed strongly last year, and also has been one of the best YTD performers in the insurance space. A return to growth in earnings should help re-rate the stock, and traditionally Admiral used to trade in the mid-to-high teens. Admittedly this was supported by the strong yield as well, as Admiral grew market share and became a significant player in UK motor, but today’s results point to the dividend yield also remaining strong in the medium term.

undefined
11:49 am
PM

Some people were discussng this Goldman stuff on commods

PM

I have a copy

PM

1.

Market views on reflation, realignment and re-levering have driven a premature surge in commodity prices that we believe is not sustainable. Last year commodity prices were driven lower by deflation, divergence and deleveraging which were reinforcing through a negative feedback loop. Deflationary pressures from excess commodity supply reinforced divergence in US growth and a stronger US dollar which in turn exacerbated EM funding costs and the need for EMs to de-lever though lower investment and hence commodity demand. While we believe that these dynamics likely ran their course last year resulting in signs of rebalancing, the force of their reversal has created a new trend in market positioning that could run further. However, the longer they run, the more destabilizing they become to the nascent rebalancing they are trying to price.

2.

The reversal started last month with ‘green shoots’ of rebalancing. Deflation turned into reflation with evidence of long-awaited oil supply curtailments in both the US and other non-OPEC producers which supported energy prices. Divergence lost out to realignment with increased fears about US economic growth. This together with strength of EU manufacturing data over the same period and a pickup in China credit data in January led the market to question the idea that the US is fundamentally outperforming its peers. These worries are reflected in the recent weakness of the US dollar and strength in the gold price. And recent policy announcements in China combined with the pickup in Chinese credit raised the prospects of leverage-driven investment demand as a focus on de-leveraging faded.

3.

While these dynamics could run further, they simply are not sustainable in the current environment, in our view. Energy needs lower prices to maintain financial stress to finish the rebalancing process; otherwise, an oil price rally will prove self-defeating as it did last spring. The most recent macro data coming out of the US reinforces US growth divergence. Increases in core CPI, strong employment growth and a rebound in manufacturing, pushed the US MAP score – a metric for how much macro data surprises – up significantly to nearly positive for the first time in 2016. Most importantly, our US economics team continues to expect solid consumer spending growth of 2.5% to 3.0% in 2016. Finally, credit growth in China remains too high relative to GDP growth underscoring the need for de-leveraging.

PM

While we still believe oil will likely rebalance this year and create a deficit market by year end, ‘green shoots’ of a deficit alone are not sufficient for a new sustainable bull market. Only a real physical deficit can create a sustainable rally which is still months away should the behavioral shifts created by the low prices in January and February remain in place. Commodity markets are physical spot markets, not anticipatory financial markets that are driven by expectations. This is why an early rally in oil prices would prove self-defeating before a real deficit materializes as it would reverse the supply curtailments that are expected to rebalance the market in 2H16.

5.

The ‘green shoots’ for oil include US E&P’s guiding production lower (c.600 kb/d), supply disruptions in Iraq and Nigeria (c.750 kb/d), non-OPEC ex-US producers reporting significant potential reductions (c.400 kb/d) and strong US oil demand. While the Iraqi and Nigerian disruptions will likely prove temporary, they do help in the rebalancing process and have likely helped to tighten Brent timespreads. However, the other green shoots are both price sensitive and are still more relevant for expectations of rebalancing, than the rebalancing seen to date. The current oil market is still in a large surplus as witnessed by last week’s large US inventory build and the large global stock overhang. To keep the financial pressure on producers, we maintain our near-term view of a trendless oil market with substantial volatility between $40/bbl (under which creates financial stress) and $20/bbl (under which creates operational stress).

6.

We also maintain our bearish view on gold that has rallied along with the other commodities. Our short gold recommendation (which we opened with a 17% upside, in line with our $1000/toz 12-m forecast) is currently at a c.5% loss, with a stop loss at 7%. This gold rally was driven by a lack of conviction in divergence in US growth as a weak US dollar has been highly correlated with a higher gold price. We believe this realignment view of weak global growth is not supported by the US data, which will likely reinforce higher US yields, a stronger US dollar and the return of divergence, particularly should strong US consumer growth dissolve market fears regarding US growth. This in turn will likely put downward pressure on gold prices towards our near-term target of $1100/toz (current price is $1265/toz).

Foxtons’ full year EBITDA was flat on the prior year with branch
expansion offsetting a weaker transactions market and tight stock
levels in lettings. Management is cautious on the outlook and we
retain our view that maintaining market share over the medium
term will be a significant challenge if Foxton’s premium fees are

BE

Final results. Revenues were 4.1% ahead to £149.8m though EBITDA was
0.4% lower at £46.0m with the margin 140bps lower at 30.7%, largely due to the
costs of new branches (seven were opened in the year). PBT was 2.6% lower at
£41.0m, with EPS of 12.3p and the full year dividend of 11.0p per share (2014:
9.7p). The balance sheet remains in a strong position with net cash of £25.6m
(2014: £22.5m).
Divisional trading. Revenues grew in all divisions, with sales (48% of group)
3.4% higher, lettings (46% of group) 2.3% higher and mortgage broking (6% of
group) 32% higher. This was largely driven by branch expansion with a 15%
increase in average branch numbers to 55 in the year. The costs of these branches
contributed to a slip in margins with the sales margin 70bps lower at 32.6% and
lettings 230bps lower at 30.1%. Overall, group margins were 140bps lower at
30.7%. The group has opened four new branches already in 2016, with another
three planned for later in the year.

11:55 am

Outlook. 2015 was a challenging year for the industry, with London transactions
c11% lower and lettings characterised by tenants staying in properties for longer,
resulting in lower levels of rental stock. There is little change expected in 2016,
with management expecting a modest improvement in London transactions and
the group’s growth to be largely driven by the branch expansion programme. We
retain our concerns about Foxtons sustaining its premium fees, particularly as it
grows its branch network into outer London where commission levels can be
significantly lower than central London.
Forecasts and valuation. We leave our forecasts unchanged at this stage. The
shares have fallen by c18% in the year to date and currently trade on a 2016E PE
of 12.4x and offer a yield of 7.6% (though this is thinly covered c1.1x by
earnings). We remain cautious on the outlook for traditional estate agencies (in
light of the growing presence of cheaper hybrid agents). In particular, we retain
our concerns about the long term sustainability of Foxtons’ market share and
relatively high commission rates. We do not believe Foxtons’ shares are ones to
Hold for the long term.

And Canaccord.

BE

These results are behind our original forecasts for FY15 but in line with what was expected after the trading update provided on 3 February. The much anticipated bounce back in the UK property market after the General Election in May did not materialise, thus leading to a continued subdued market, particularly in London where transaction numbers were well below the long-run average.

The number of properties available for sale as reported by RICS has increased through the beginning of 2016, and we are confident that Foxtons is well positioned to capture an increase in activity in its regions of operation. The continued branch expansion will help the business maintain high margins as it moves into high volume areas with less established competition.

We believe that the growth trajectory of the business remains unchanged and are confident in the Group's capability to assess geographic areas of significant opportunity regarding both house price growth and increasing transaction volumes.

We continue to monitor both the RICS residential market survey and the Land Registry House Price Index on a monthly basis for information regarding historical transaction numbers, price growth, and general market sentiment.

BE

Celtic is a well-managed, conservatively funded football club with an increasingly dominant position in the Scottish Professional Football League (SPFL). It’s a big fish in a small pond, but it has the fan-base, facilities and management focus to be a big fish in a big pond. The business is conservatively managed within its financial means with the trading upside coming from performing well in the UEFA Europa League or, better still, Champions' League. We assume coverage and reiterate our BUY recommendation with a new 110p share price target (previously 103p), implying 48% potential upside.

BE

Celtic has three revenue streams, which are derived from the commercial exploitation of its nine million fan base: stadium income, merchandising and media rights. The Club's stadium, Celtic Park, is a world class facility with a 60,000+ all-seater capacity and its average league match-day attendance (45,400 for the 2014-15 season) is commensurate with the best clubs in Europe and would rank it fourth among English Premier League (EPL) clubs. It is also better than the 43,502 average for Bundesliga league matches, the best-attended association football league in the world. Celtic generates £13m to £15m per annum from merchandising. The key media opportunity is from TV rights. We estimate that Celtic’s current domestic TV revenue is worth c£2m. In comparison, the new EPL deal will be worth £100m in revenue to the bottom club.

Winning games, of course, has a direct impact on financial performance. Last season Celtic was winner of the Scottish League Cup, it won the Scottish Premiership for the fourth year in succession and it fell at the Europa League, Round of 32. This year Celtic is lying first in the Premiership, it reached the semi-final of the League Cup and it fell at the group stage of the Europa League. Celtic should have generated +£6m from European games this season. Progression to the Champions League would have been worth more than £13m.

Youth development is important and the club continues to generate a flow of Development and U19 players into the senior squad. Celtic also has a good track record of making profits from player transfers. In 2014 it sold Victor Wanyama to Southampton for a reported £12m. In 2015 Celtic sold goalkeeper Fraser Forster to Southampton for £10m. 2016 will also be a good year following the reported £13m sale of defender Virgil van Dijk to Southampton and the sale of Adam Matthews to Sunderland for a £2m fee.

12:00 pm
BE

We derive our 110p target price by applying a 15% discount (rounded up) to our 128p sum-of-the-parts valuation. The discount reflects the low free float (41%) of the shares and the variable nature of the industry. We believe the current valuation reflects the current status quo, but ignores both the longer-term potential of this global franchise and the current intrinsic value embedded in the stadium, playing squad and consistent trading performance. Shorter term, a good run in the UEFA Europa League or preferably in the Champions’ League would boost performance. Longer term, Celtic joining a reconstituted Premier League or European based league would offer substantial upside.
